 I. 

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on (i)  a proposed
loan to Power Grid Corporation of India Limited (Powergrid), guaranteed by India, for the Power
Transmission Improvement (Sector) Project; and (ii) a proposed partial credit guarantee by the
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  of  an  international  commercial  cofinancing  to  Powergrid,
counter-guaranteed by India, intended to cofinance the Project.

I. 

INTRODUCTION

The  Indian  power  sector  is  currently  undergoing  reforms  at  both  the  central  (federal)
2.
and state (provincial) levels. The reforms continue to be supported by ADB at both levels and
are  now  approaching  self-sustainability  at  the  central  level  where  Powergrid  is  playing  an
important role in initiating and accelerating the reform process through increasing competition in
the  sector  and  through  greater  commercialization.  Powergrid’s  investments  are,  therefore,
accorded priority by the Government of India. This loan will be ADB’s second loan in support of
Powergrid’s  operations.  For  India,  this  will  be  the  first  time  that  international  commercial
cofinancing  is  raised  using  ADB's  partial  credit  guarantee  after  approval  of  the  ADB's  new
Guarantee  Policy  in  1995.    Loan  fact-finding  was  carried  out  during  11-22  May  1998  and
appraisal from 7 to 19 September 1998.1

Powergrid’s  investment  program  is  well  conceived  and  meets  the  priority  needs  of  the
3.
national economy.  Powergrid’s competence as an executing agency has been demonstrated by
the successful implementation of the ongoing loan 2, including its policy issues. A sector loan is
therefore considered appropriate to finance a portion of Powergrid’s investments over the next
five  years.    Through  the  sector  loan  approach,  ADB  can  support  Powergrid  to  improve  power
system performance, facilitate further sector reform in central sector agencies, as well as cause
states  to  accelerate  their  power  sector  reforms.  A  sector  loan  approach  will  internalize  the
process  of  choosing  subprojects  that  meet  technical,  financial,  economic,  environmental,  and
social criteria appropriate to modernizing the sector. The sector loan approach will also provide
Powergrid  with  sufficient  flexibility  to  optimally  utilize  the  commercial  cofinancing  raised  using
ADB’s partial credit guarantee facility. Appendix 1 gives the project framework.

II. 

BACKGROUND

4.

is important for India to adopt a macroeconomic framework conducive to ensuring sustainable
growth,  the  Government  needs  to  pay  equal  attention  to  removing  infrastructure  deficiencies
that present severe bottlenecks in the continued expansion of the economy. Estimates indicate
that the level of investment in infrastructure needs to be increased by almost 50 percent in real

5.
Electricity  is  one  of  the  key  inputs  for  India’s  overall  socioeconomic  development,
especially in commercial and industrial activities, and has strong linkage to other infrastructure
such as transportation and telecommunications. Basic human needs such as water supply and
sewerage,  and  many  social  welfare  activities  such  as  education  and  health  care,  are  also
directly or indirectly supported by electricity supply. Although India’s power sector has expanded
rapidly,  continuous  power  shortages,  combined  with  poor  quality  of  supply,  severely  constrain
economic development in almost all parts of the country.

6.
The  development  of  the  power  sector  is  currently  limited  by  two  major  factors:  public
sector  funding  constraints,  and  the  absence  of  the  required  long-term  policy  and  regulatory
framework for enhanced private investment in the sector. Public sector funding constraints are
directly  linked  to  the  broader  issue  of  the  system  of  subsidies  in  the  Indian economy.  In  fiscal
year  (FY)1999,  total  budgetary  subsidies  at  the  central  and  state  levels  amounted  to
Rs557.26 billion ($12.8 billion), or over 3.1 percent of India's gross domestic product.

7.
Of these subsidies, Rs225.37 billion ($5.18 billion), or about 40 percent of the total, was
channeled to the power sector to compensate the utilities for the lower-than-supply cost tariffs
for certain consumers groups. Adjustment of tariffs to achieve higher cost recovery not only is
crucial  to  increase  the  self-financing  position  of  public  sector  power  entities  but  has  a  direct
bearing on further commercialization and privatization of the power sector. The chronic financial
difficulties  of  most  state  electricity  boards  (SEBs)  account  for  much  of  the  sector’s  difficulties.
Collectively, SEBs have a high level of accounts payable to central power agencies that supply
electricity to them, threatening the financial viability of these agencies.

8.
The present status of the power sector also reflects attempts to politically manage such
a large and complex system, and the limited autonomy under which many of the power utilities
operate. Establishing an independent regulatory body at central and state levels is essential to
ensure  the  commercial  and  technical  soundness  of  the  power  sector  and  the  autonomy  of
power sector entities from political interference.

A. 

Power Sector Overview

1. 

Organization

9.
India consists of 25 states and 7 union territories with a total population of over 1 billion.
Its  power  sector  is  the  third  largest  in  Asia  after  that  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and
Japan. Installed generation capacity grew from about 2,000 megawatts (MW) in 1950 to about
98,000 MW as of 31 March 2000, with an additional 12,000 MW of captive generation capacity.
There  are  more  than  77 million  electricity  consumers  and  about  86  percent  of  villages  have
been electrified. However, the annual per capita consumption was only about 360 kilowatt-hours
(kWh)  in  FY2000,  which  is  lower  than  the  consumption  levels  of  many  other  developing
countries.

10.
The  organization  of  the  power  sector  is  determined  by  India’s  federal  structure.  The
Government’s  Ministry  of  Power  provides  overall  guidance  to  the  sector,  mainly  through  the
Central  Electricity  Authority  (CEA),  and  owns  the  central  power  sector  utilities  such  as  the
National  Thermal  Power  Corporation  (NTPC),  the  National  Hydro-electric  Power  Corporation
(NHPC), the Nuclear Power Corporation (NPC), and Powergrid, and financing institutions such

 3

as  the  Power  Finance  Corporation  (PFC)  and  the  Rural  Electrification  Corporation.  State
governments  control  the  rest  of  the  sector  through  17 SEBs  and  12  electricity  departments
(EDs). These SEBs and EDs provide distribution facilities and set retail tariffs. Power generation
and  transmission  are  split  between  the  central  power  sector  agencies  and  SEBs.  The  central
agencies  own  and  operate  32 percent  of  the  country’s  total  generation,  while  SEBs  and  EDs
have  64  percent  of  the  total.  In  addition,  five  private  utilities  in  urban  agglomerations  have  a
share of 4 percent in power generation.

11.
As a result of India’s federal structure, all major issues affecting the power sector require
concurrent action by the Government and state governments. Although the structure gives the
Government  a  say  in  the  affairs  of  the  power  sectors  of  the  states,  this  shared  responsibility
limits  the  Government’s  ability  to  influence  the  power  sector  policies  of  state  governments,
especially with respect to retail tariffs.

2. 

State Electricity Boards

12.
Prior to the reorganization of the power sectors in the states of Orissa (1996), Haryana
(1998), Andhra Pradesh (1999), Karnataka (1999), and Uttar Pradesh (2000), the power sector
in  every  major  state  was  organized  through  its  SEB.  Even  today,  other  than  in  these  states,
SEBs  still  control  the  operations  of  the  sector.  The  Electricity  Act  of  1910  and  the  Electricity
Supply  Act  of  1948  with  their  several  amendments  provide  the  legal  basis  for  the  sector’s
functioning  and  utilities’  operation.  These  acts  allow  considerable  managerial  and  financial
autonomy  to  the  SEBs,  but  this  autonomy  is  often  nominal  as  most  state  governments  use
SEBs to pursue noncommercial objectives, particularly to provide low-priced or free electricity to
the agriculture sector. Initially, this cross-subsidization was done to provide low-cost inputs for
agriculture  to  stimulate  food  production  and  was  very  successful.  However,  that  stage  is  now
well past but  the practice has continued largely to attract political support. State governments
also  tend  to  interfere  with  SEB’s  day-to-day  operations,  thus  complicating  the  task  of  SEB
management.  These  interventions  have  led  to  the  SEBs’  deteriorating  financial  health,  which
has become the central problem of India’s power sector.

13.
Several years of negative internal cash generation has impoverished the SEBs, impeded
the construction of new power facilities, and restricted the funds available for maintenance and
rehabilitation  of  existing  assets,  thus  making  it  impossible  to  close  the  demand-supply  gap.
Chronic power shortages and poor quality of power supply continue to plague the economy in
almost all parts of the country. If not remedied, the unavailability of sufficient power will be the
single most important constraint to economic development in the coming years and will thwart
the Government’s efforts to attract domestic and foreign investment.

14.
A reform of the power sector at the state level is urgently needed to reduce the need for
subsidies and public spending on the sector. As a result of the state governments' interference
in  SEB  operation  and  subsidies  to  agriculture  customers,  the  sector’s  losses  in  FY1999
aggregated  to  Rs63.3  billion  ($1.4  billion),  but  were  reduced  to  Rs45.0 billion  ($1.0  billion)  by
subsidies from state governments. Power sector reform would significantly reduce claims on the
country’s fiscal resources and allow additional spending on other priority sectors such as health
and education, which are essential for poverty reduction.

3. 

Central Power Utilities

15.
Until  1972,  the  SEBs  were  almost  solely  responsible  for  development  of  power
generation and transmission within their states but were unable to meet the rapidly increasing

 4

demand for electricity. To improve the efficiency of generation, three central sector agencies -
NTPC, NHPC and NPC, were established in 1975 to generate bulk power for sale to SEBs. In
1989,  Powergrid  was  established  as  a  transmission  and  dispatch  company  by  amalgamating
the transmission and dispatch assets of all central power sector agencies. In addition to these
wholly  owned  companies,  the  Government  also  has  shares  in  special-purpose  generating
companies such as the Bhakra-Beas Management Board, the Damodar Valley Corporation, the
Tehri Power Corporation, the Nathpa-Jhakhri Power Corporation, the North-East Electric Power
Corporation, and the Neyveli Lignite Corporation.

The central agencies, including NTPC, NHPC, and Powergrid, are seriously affected by
16.
the  poor  financial  health  of  most  SEBs,  as  was  evidenced  several  times  in  the  past  when
excessive accounts receivable from the SEBs seriously impaired the central agencies’ financial
liquidity.  To  resolve  this  problem,  NTPC  has,  in  addition  to  restricting  supply  and  obtaining
Government appropriation to settle debts of SEBs, even resorted to taking over the generation
facilities of SEBs in settlement of accounts receivable.3

4.

Powergrid

17.
Prior  to  1991,  NTPC  and  other  central  sector  generating  companies  constructed  and
operated the transmission facilities to evacuate power from their power plants and transmit the
power  to  client  SEBs.  As  the  transmission  systems  grew,  it  was  recognized  that  it  would  be
more  efficient  to  have  a  national  transmission  utility  that  would  be  responsible  for  the
transmission  systems  required  to  evacuate  power  from  the  central  sector  power  plants,  and
construct  and  operate  the  transmission  and  dispatch  facilities  required  for  power  interchange
among SEBs within a region and for interchanges between regions.

18.
To  serve  that  purpose,  Powergrid  was  established  in  October  1989  as  a  Government-
owned corporation and commenced operation in late 1991. It has been profitable since its first
full year of commercial operation in FY1993, and is expected to remain so. The development of
Powergrid was planned in three phases. The first phase, which was completed in 1992, involved
the transfer of transmission facilities and associated staff from the other central sector agencies
to Powergrid. The second phase of development involved taking over from CEA  the operations
of the regional system coordination centers (RSCCs) and associated communication facilities in
each region. This was accomplished in 1996.

The  third  phase,  which  is  ongoing,  is  the  development  of  a  national  transmission  grid
19.
and  facilities  for  intensified  interregional  cooperation  and  coordination.  Transmission  links

in  frequency.  The  development  of  a  national  grid  will  enhance  operational  efficiency  by  the
sharing of reserve margins, trading of surplus generation between regions, and long-term power
transfer from regions with low-cost hydropower or coal resources. Powergrid will now construct
and  operate  new  RSCC  facilities,  which  will  improve  the  coordination  of  regional  grids  and
facilitate bulk power trading between SEBs. Development of additional transmission facilities for

B. 

Government Policies and Plans

1. 

Overall Power Sector Reform

21.
Despite  the  rapid  expansion  of  the  Indian  power  system  over  the  last  50  years,  power
shortage is currently estimated to be about 11.3 percent of peak load and 8.3 percent of energy

2. 

Sector Reform at State Level

On account of their high technical and nontechnical losses, as well as the low tariffs set
26.

expansion, renovation, and modernization programs. Weak financial and commercial viability of
SEBs is also inhibiting private entrepreneurs from participating in the entire power sector from
generation through transmission to distribution. Therefore, the most critical part of sector reform
is at the state level. State governments must resolve three major issues: (i) the tariff structure
needs  to  be  revised  to  reflect  the  cost  of  supply  based  on  metered  energy;  (ii)  subsidies  to
specific  customer  categories  should  be  provided  explicitly  through  institutional  measures  such

utility  business  on  a  commercial  basis.  In  principle,  the  Government  and  state  governments

generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  and  vesting  these  functional  responsibilities  with
different  entities;  (ii)  corporatization  of  the  new  successor  entities;  (iii)  establishment  of  an
independent body to regulate sector issues such as tariff setting; and (iv) facilitation of private
sector participation in generation and; if viable and justified, in distribution and transmission.

Powergrid’s Role in the Reforms

33.
The  three-phase  development  of  Powergrid’s  transmission  systems  and  operations
described in paras. 18 and 19 will facilitate the restructuring of the power sector into separate
and more efficient generation and distribution companies. The development of the regional and
national transmission grids and control centers will also improve the coordination and efficiency
of power sector operations on regional and national basis. The World Bank’s study "India: Long-
Term  Issues  in  the  Power  Sector,"  prepared  in  1991,  concluded  that  improved  coordination  in
system  operations,  through  such  measures  as  effective  operation  of  the  regional  grids  and

prevailing level of about 9 percent of total energy demand. Potential savings through improved
coordination in operations and commercialization were estimated at $5 billion to $10 billion by

facilities  were  developed  for  national  power  trading.  The  combined  savings  were  found  to  be
equivalent to about 10 percent of the total capital investment required in the power sector over
this  period.  Clearly,  Powergrid  has  a  major  role  to  play  in  improving  the  efficiency  and
productivity of India’s power sector.

D. 

Lessons Learned

1. 

Overall Bank Operations

43.
The  operations  of  ADB  and  other  aid  agencies  in  the  power  sector  in  India  have
generally been successful from a project point of view; i.e., the projects concerned have been
completed, although with implementation delays, and performed to the desired technical levels.
However,  except  for  the  ongoing  loan  to  Powergrid,  these  projects  were  not  designed  to
change  the  business  environment,  and  the  sector  performance  has  continued  to  deteriorate,
although  the  operations  of  the  project  components,  taken  individually,  were    satisfactory.  This
was  primarily  on  account  of  the  (i) political  interference  in  tariff  setting;  (ii) rapid  growth  of  the
demand for electricity, making conventional investment strategies unworkable; (iii) government
rules and regulations and control of the SEBs that inhibited speedy decision making; and (iv) the
noncommercial  setup  of  the  sector  that  did  not  generate  the  market  for  alternative  players  to
step in to bridge the gap between supply and demand.

44.
In the past, ADB extended assistance to discrete power projects in various states as well
as  to  the  central  power  sector  agencies.  Although  this  policy  enabled  ADB  to  support  many
projects, it spread ADB's resources too thinly, with the result that it could not achieve its desired
goal of policy reforms with its power sector borrowers. In most states, the power sector was the
largest recipient of state resources, in terms of both subsidies and in terms capital investments,
and it was realized that macro management of the state's finances needed to be improved for
the successful turnaround of the power sector. Therefore, ADB is now assisting states for power
sector reforms only in the context of a holistic change in their macroeconomic management.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

ADB’s  operational  strategy  in  India  is  to  support  efforts  to  achieve  higher  sustainable
48.

focuses  on  improving  the  supply  side  efficiency  of  the  economy,  especially  by  reducing
bottlenecks in key infrastructure sectors. Emphasis is on improving the policy, institutional, and
regulatory  framework  so  as  to  enhance  the  efficiency  of  public  sector  operations  and  to
encourage  private  investment.  Improving  resource  mobilization  to  finance  the  necessary
investments is a key component of ADB’s assistance, and includes support for the development
of  financial  and  capital  markets  as  well  as  for  improving  internal  resource  mobilization  in  the
sector  agencies  and  enhancing  their  creditworthiness.  High  priority  is  also  given  to  assisting
projects that contribute to environmental improvement.

ADB's  strategy  for  India  was  revised  in  1996  to  accommodate  an  urgent  need  for  a
49.

Availability-based  tariffs  19  are  necessary  for  competitive  merit  order  dispatch  of

generation to its consumers. In India, this has not been possible on account of the plant-load-
factor-based tariff currently in force for generation stations. As part of policy dialogue under its
ongoing loan activity,  ADB requested the Government and Powergrid to examine the feasibility
of  introducing  availability-based  tariff  for  at  least  central  sector  generation  in  every  electricity

B.

65.

system  reliability,  reduce  transmission  losses,  improve  system  quality,  and  allow  efficient
utilization of existing and planned generation plants. The strategic objectives are to (i) support
the  restructuring  of  India’s  power  sector;  (ii)  enable  private  sector  participation,  (iii) encourage
the adoption of appropriate pricing mechanisms for all bulk supply of electricity; and (iv) improve
the  commercial  basis  for  all  transmission  transactions,  thus  ensuring  Powergrid's  profitability,
liquidity,  and  ability  to  mobilize  more  commercial  counterpart  funds.  The  Project  will  also  help

through  market-based  programs,  thus  making  Powergrid  more  autonomous  and  commercially
oriented.

132  kV  transmission  systems  to  transfer  additional  power,  to  improve  system  reliability,  and
enhance  the  efficient  utilization  of  power  plants;  and  Part  B:  installing  400  kV  and  220  kV

state benefiting from the new transmission lines, after deducting for auxiliary consumption, and
transmission and distribution losses.

b. 

Generation-Linked Schemes

111. NTPC is expanding three of its gas-fired generation facilities at Anta in Rajasthan State,
and  Gandhar  and  Kawas  in  Gujarat  State.  These  facilities  are  to  be  constructed  within  the
premises of already existing plants, making extensive use of facilities on site and rights-of-way
to  achieve  economies  of  scale.  The  alternative  would  have  been  to  build  coal-fired  power
stations and to transport the coal from far-off mines. However, NTPC determined in 1993 that
transporting the high-ash coal available in India beyond 400 km is uneconomical and also leads
to environmental problems related to disposal of the residual ash especially in populated areas.

112. While  the  power  evacuation  project  associated  with  the  Anta-II  generation  project  is  in
the northern region, those associated with the Kawas-II and Gandhar-II generation projects are
in the western region. The general approach used to evaluate transmission lines linked to new
generation plants is to compare the total incremental economic cost of generation, transmission
from and distribution with the incremental economic benefits. The benefits are estimated on the
value of the power supply to the final consumers, calculated separately for the major consumer
categories  in  each  state  supplied  by  the  new  power  plants,  after  deducting  for  auxiliary
consumption, and transmission and distribution losses.  Sent-out costs per kWh from the new
generation plants were taken from the respective feasibility studies and were adjusted to reflect
economic costs.

113.
The three power plants are all designed to use natural gas as well as naphtha and the
feasibility studies ran calculations for sent-out costs for both types of fuel. Use of natural gas in
the plants depends on the development of gas terminals, and Memorandum of Understanding
for  the  construction  of  two  terminals  dedicated  to  serve  the  three  plants  were  signed  in  early
2000. The terminals are expected to come into operation by end-2003, which is approximately
six  months  after  the  construction  of  the  power  plants  will  be  completed.  In  the  economic
evaluation of the transmission projects, variable sent-out costs were calculated on the basis of a
liquefied natural gas (LNG) price of $4 per million Btu. However, for the first year of the plants
operations,  it  was  assumed  that  indigenous  naphtha  would  be  used  at  a  cost  of  Rs17,000
($382) per ton.

114. Associated investments in distribution facilities to utilize the incremental power from the
new  power  stations  had  been  assumed  for  states  that  are  allocated  more  than  100  MW.  For
states  with  allocations  below  100  MW,  it  was  assumed  that  this  incremental  power  will  be
utilized  to  offset  the  current  power-supply  shortages.  Therefore  only  incremental  O&M  cost
related to distribution services were assumed.

The  EIRRs  were  estimated  to  be  36  percent  for  Anta-II,  24  percent  for  Kawas-II,  and

3. 

Risks

117.
The Project involves no major risk. Powergrid is required to provide internally generated
funds  to  finance  20  percent  of  the  project  cost.  The  risk  of  shortfall  in  this  is  low  because  its
funds resources are expected to be comfortably above this requirement from FY2000 onward.
Also, since the project expenditure forms only part of Powergrid’s capital expenditure program,
the Project will be given priority. From Powergrid’s past performance, especially in the ongoing
loan,  technical,  environmental,  and  social  risks  are  minimal.  Since  all  foreign  exchange
fluctuations are a pass-through to the transmission service tariff, the only risk would arise from
delays in tariff increase. However, the establishment of CERC minimizes this risk. Demand risk
is  minimal  since  the  national  construction  program  is  planning  for  shortages,  even  after  its
completion. If demand growth is lower than that assumed, the satisfaction level will increase. In
any case the identified subprojects are part of the least-cost solutions, and therefore  will always
enjoy priority over other investments in transmission.  The only risk arises from the deferment of
the  construction  of  the  generation  projects  of  NTPC  to  which  these  transmission  systems  are
linked.  This  risk  has  been  mitigated  by  delaying  subproject  implementation  until  a  reasonable
level of commitment has been received from NTPC. The EIRR of the Project has been tested
for delays of up to two years for completion of the generation facilities and has been found to be
robust.

B. 

Environment

118.
The transmission subprojects and the implementation of the availability tariff will reduce
the  total  output  of  pollutants  from  power  plants  by  enforcing  the  optimal  use  of  generation
facilities  through  (i)  a  tariff  structure  that  ensures  economical  load  dispatching  wherein  least-
cost  hydropower  and  efficient  thermal  plants  have  the  highest  position  in  the  merit  order;
(ii) transferring electricity from one regional grid to another to benefit from the diversity in peak
demand hours and optimizing the interregional use of power plants; and (iii) reducing demands
to  transport  coal  with  a  very  high  ash  content  on  the  overloaded  railroad  systems,  which  will
lead  to  environmental  benefits  from  reduced  ash  disposal.  Energy  resources  will  be  saved  by
reducing  transmission  losses,  improving  voltage  and  frequency,  and  decreasing  system
overloading.  The  availability  of  improved  power  supply  will  reduce  the  use  of  uneconomical
captive power generation.

C. 

Social Dimensions

The  Project  will  benefit  industrial,  commercial,  residential,  and  agriculture  customers
119.
throughout India. It will allow India to supply electricity to additional households and to have a
more  reliable  supply  of  power.  By  inducing  industrial  and  commercial  activity,  the  Project  will
create  more  job  opportunities  and  improve  productivity  and  the  quality  of  outputs  in  the
manufacturing sector.

D. 

Poverty Reduction

The Indian economy needs to grow by about 7 percent per annum to significantly reduce
120.
poverty  over  the  next  20  years.  Availability  of  low-cost  reliable  power  is  one  of  the  key
requirements  for  such  growth.  By  supporting  provision  of  low-cost  power,  the  Project  is
contributing to pro-poor growth in the country.

Power  Grid  Corporation  of  India  Limited  (POWERGRID)  is  a  limited-liability  company

utility  responsible  for  evacuating  power  from  central  power  plants  and  for  developing  and
operating  transmission  facilities  to  enable  power  interchange  among  state  electricity  boards
both within and between regions.

Powergrid has a total authorized capital of Rs50 billion, comprising of 50 million shares
2.
with  a  par  value  of  Rs1,000  per  share.  As  of  31  March  2000,  28,886,540  shares  had  been
issued for a total paid-up and subscribed capital of Rs30,495 million (including a share capital
deposit of Rs1,609 million). Powergrid is 100 percent owned by the Government of India.

B. 

Past Financial Performance

3.
Powergrid  commenced  commercial  operations  in  August  1991  and  has  been  profitable
in  each  year  with  the  exception  of  the  first  partial  year  of  operations.  Since  31  March  1993,
sales  have  grown  at  an  average  rate  of  18  percent  per  annum,  with  net  profit  increasing  by
approximately 9 percent per annum. Total operating expenses have been less than 11 percent
of net fixed assets.

4.
Powergrid has maintained positive cash flow from operations. Continued expansion has
been  financed  partially  through  internally  generated  funds,  equity  contributions  from  the
Government, and a combination of short-, medium-, and long-term debt.

5.
While maintaining a positive cash flow and a relatively strong balance sheet, Powergrid
is  facing  some  difficulty  with  collecting  accounts  receivable.  Accounts  receivable  amounted  to
8.4  months  of  sales  at  the  end  of  FY2000.  The  Asian  Development  Bank's  loan  covenant
stipulated  that  accounts  receivable  should  represent  no  more  than  2.0  months  of  sales.  The
Government has approved a provision of Rs3,460 million as central appropriation to Powergrid
to liquidate the outstanding accounts receivable as of 31 March 1997. Rs1,075 million had been
received as of 31 March 2000, and the balance of Rs2,385 million will be received over the next
seven years.  After taking into account the component of accounts receivable to be paid through
the  central  appropriation,  the  adjusted  accounts  receivable  balance  as  of  31  March  2000
represents 5.6 months sales.

Economic Benefits

2.
Base  data  and  assumptions  used  with  respect  to  the  estimation  of  economic  benefits

segments: domestic, commercial, industrial, and agriculture.

3.
Each  subproject  was  analyzed  as  to  which  states  would  benefit  from  the  incremental

state and consumer segment.

4.
The shares of electricity supply assumed to replace an alternative energy source in each
consumer  category  are  the  following:  10  percent  for  domestic,  50  percent  for  commercial  and
industrial,  and  20  percent  for  agriculture.  The  economic  benefit  of  fuel  substitution  is  the
resulting  economic  resource  cost  saving,  that  is,  the  economic  cost  of  alternative  energy  that
the country saves by using electricity.

5.
The shares of incremental electricity supply corresponding to induced consumption are
90  percent  for  domestic,  50  percent  for  commercial  and  industrial,  and  80  percent  for
agriculture.  Induced  consumption  was  valued  by  estimating  the  consumer’s  willingness  to  pay
for this part of incremental electricity supply and adding the related consumer surplus benefits to
the tariff-based revenues.

6.
Alternative  sources  of  power  used  by  the  four  major  consumer  segments  were
determined and their respective costs were estimated.  It was found that the dominant source of
alternative  power  in  the  domestic  sector  is  kerosene  lamps.    Urban  domestic  consumers  use
LPG  lights  (Petromax)  and  candles  in  addition  to  kerosene  lamps.  Rural  domestic  consumers
rely  almost  entirely  on  kerosene  lamps.  Private  ownership  of  small  and  medium-size  diesel
generators is very low and is prevalent only among high-income  consumers. Roughly around
50 percent of total end-consumption of alternative sources of power in the domestic sector is for
lighting  purposes.  In  the  rural  areas,  these  numbers  are  considerably  higher  due  to  the
significantly  lower  ownership  of  electrical  appliances.  Thus,  during  power  cuts,  substitution  for
electricity  is  almost  exclusively  for  lighting  purposes.  Therefore,  economic  benefits  for  the
domestic sector were calculated only for 50 percent of total domestic consumption.

7.
This  50  percent  share  was  allocated  over  three  to  four  alternative  energy  sources
depending  on  the  state.  For  example,  while  it  can  be  expected  that  about  5  percent  of
customers in Gujarat and Maharastha own small diesel generators, this is highly unlikely to be
the  case  in  Madhya  Pradesh.  Therefore,  only  kerosene  lamps,  inverters,  and  kerosene
generator sets were used for calculating alternative energy cost in Madhya Pradesh. However,
the  assumed  percentage of  ownership of these  three alternative  energy forms varies  with
the  economic  profile  of  each  state.  Induced  consumption  was  valued  using  the  willingness-to-
pay method plus the related consumer surplus with a curvature factor of 0.3.

Conclusion

On  the  basis  of  a  comparison  of  economic  costs  and  benefits  over  a  20-year  project
17.
lifetime,  the  proposed  subprojects  all  show  EIRR  well  above  the  social  discount  rate  of  12
percent (Table A 14.3). Extensive sensitivity testing was carried out for the five subprojects. In
addition  to  the  traditional  testing  for  increases  in  capital  costs,  decreases  in  benefits,  and
implementation  delays,  further  variables  considered  crucial  parameters  for  economic  viability
were  identified.  Testing  for  changes  in  the  replacement  and  incremental  shares  of  additional
energy  for  the  different  consumer  groups  showed  very  low  sensitivity,  with  no  impact  on  the
viability of the subprojects. Further reduction of domestic consumer benefits to only 15 and 30
percent of total domestic consumption shows that all projects will stay viable with the exception
of  Anta-  II  where  the  EIRR  would  drop  to  10  percent  if  only  15  percent  of  total  domestic
consumption  is  included  in  the  benefit  stream.  Sensitivity  testing  for  sent-out  cost  of  power
showed that the viability of the Anta- II subproject depends critically on the availability of LNG as
a fuel source for the proposed new generation plant. If naphtha would need to be used during
the first year of operation, the project would not be viable.

This  is  explained  by  two  particularities  of  the  subproject.  The  first  reason  is  the  higher
18.
capital cost for the plant since the existing site is not as evolved as the sites for Gandhar- II and
Kawas- II. Second, Anta- II will serve states not served by Kawas- II and Gandhar-II plants, and
thus  has  a  different  benefit  stream.    The  project  sponsors  recognized  this  sensitivity  and,  to
mitigate  the  risks,  have  decided  that  production  of  the  plant  will  only  commence  after  LNG  is
made  available.  Even  with  a  two-year  delay  between  the  finalization  of  construction  of  the
transmission  lines  and  the  commencement  of  power  generation,  the  subproject  will  be  viable.
In  the  base  case  analysis  for  the  grid-strengthening  subprojects,  power  generation  costs  from
coal-fired plants were assumed to be Rs1.2 per kWh, or double the cost indicated by NTPC and
Powergrid.  An  increase  in  the  send-out  costs  to  Rs2/kWh  shows  that  both  subprojects  would
become unviable. However, Powergrid and NTPC officially state that the sent-out costs from the
coal-fired plants are only Rs0.64/kWh as the coal plants are fully depreciated and testing for this
cost shows that both projects are very robust.
